Please excuse the awful (and dated) pun in the title. I couldn'

column1: This character was the most anticipated by far of the Series 13 cast. He'
column2: s wacky, unique, and fun. But was he worth hunting down?
t know what to say now, I always get burned out after a couple of reviews of each series on this section. The bag and pamphlet are eye-catching and appealing.&nbsp

column1: The only standout part here is the huge hot dog costume. It'
column2: s a large painted piece that slides over the head and torso, restricting leg movement. Otherwise, he&#39
column3: s pretty bland, with a plain tan torso and unprinted blue legs. His face is nice, though.&nbsp

column2: t get the hype. I like the character, he&#39
column3: s weird and silly, but also based on real life, but I don&#39
column4: t know. I have little use for him in any environment
column5: the best use in a city setting I can think of would be the Fairground Mixer set. Or a costume party. His bland torso and legs aren&#39
column6: t of much use either. I think they missed a good opportunity to give him a sausage piece, but he&#39
column7: s all right, I suppose. Just not my cup of tea.&nbsp

column1: The simplest one in the whole series, as he only includes four parts.
Get him if you want him. To me, he'
column2: s a restricted novelty character with little application in LEGO scenarios. I think they did a great job in his execution, and the costume piece is very well made, but he isn&#39
column3: t a character I would buy any more than one of.&nbsp

Great figure that would be even better if the painting on the hot dog itself was more precise.
column2: In the ones I&#39
column3: ve opened there is always some overspray and underspray between the dog and the bun. &nbsp
column4: Not a big deal really for a figure that is extremely odd and over the top and really stands out in the CMF series. &nbsp
column5: Super fun and shows that TLG can do some really silly things just when you&#39

column2: t like that one side of the included pamphlet is completely dedicated to the minifigures online website and game with a game code. &nbsp
column3: I liked when it shows all of the available character&#39

column1: The only thing lacking here is some condiments or an actual sausage/hot dog which they already manufacture.

column2: s only 4 parts, nothing interesting of note.

column1: Looks great and even acts as a conversation piece.
column3: s surprising to everyone and is a really joyful model.

column2: m quite happy to see them break the mold here and hope this means more non-animal mascots to come in future CMF series figs. &nbsp
column3: Will absolutely pair this guy up with the hot dog stand polybag that currently stands in front of the Town Hall modular.

column1:
,TRUE,5,4,3,5,4 Odeinoichus","2016-08-18T18:30:42.797Z","Hot Dogs! Get your Hot Dogs Here!","

Set #71008 Hot Dog Guy: After twelve series of previous Minifigures, and getting everything from historical characters, costumed mascots and unique characters not seen in regular Themes. But this is the first Food Mascot you'
column2: re going to see, and this is the one biggest in-demand figure from Series 13.

column1: He has no printing outside of the facial expression, he has a pair of light blue pants and a very light brown top which has no printing, why? Because everything about this figure is for the detail work in the sculpted head piece that slides over the torso and legs. The Hot Dog suit is sheer brilliance, you get to see the bun, the hot dog and a squibble of mustard with a slit in the top to see his face.

column2: re going to want so many of these characters I am going to just say it, get him. If you don&#39
column3: t collect CMFs at all you will want this figure, because he is just such a useful character for populating LEGO City displays and MOCs and everything you can imagine, baseball field MOCs, Hot Dog carts, some interesting restaurant or theater builds. Great figure.

The legs and midsection by themselves are quite boring. &nbsp

column1: Hot Dog man is actually my favorite of this series.

column1: Picked up a couple of these, for my own collection and as whimsical Lego(iconic) gifts!

,TRUE,5,3,2,3,3 The_Scooby_Fan","2015-06-28T14:01:20.307Z","Do You Know the Hot Dog Man?","

The Hot Dog Man is a cool little minifigure, one of my favorites in series thirteen. Although he'
column2: s just a regular minifig&nbsp
column3: underneath, adding the hot dog costume makes him unique.

column1: The Hot Dog Man is the easiest to feel for in this series, due to his giant hot dog suit. I never bother to check if there are instructions in these, as they are super easy to build.
The Hot Dog Guy contains all the average minifig parts, but he also contains that hot dog, which I am pretty sure is unique to this one blind bag.
Overall, the Hot Dog Guy is a great minifig.
Short, simple, easy. I enjoy building minifigs, but I can'
column2: t really build a Lego set without messing up.&nbsp

column1: The completed model fits right into my nearly complete set of minifigures series thirteen. He looks great!
I think the Hot Dog Guy is a great figure, and if you are looking for him, my advice would be to feel for the hot dog costume, you can'
column2: t miss it.

column1:
,TRUE,5,4,2,4,5 sideswinger","2022-12-06T00:24:53.157Z","I wish I were an Oscar Mayer Weiner!","

LEGO CMF'
column2: s are especially popular while sporting some sort of costume, and by this point in the CMF line, we had the Gorilla Suit Guy, Lizard Man, Bunny Suit Guy, Chicken Suit Guy, Bumblebee Girl, Panda Guy, Piggy Guy, and Unicorn Girl, all of which are based off real life animals. What non-animal costumes could LEGO come up with? Well, Series 13 includes your answer, because the first ever Collectable Minifigure food costume character was&nbsp
column3: 14th in the set. Hot Dog Man was released in January 2015, where he retailed for 4 dollars and includes 5 pieces.

column1: I think this goes without saying, but my favourite
column2: part of this figure is obviously the massive hot dog mould, which is an entirely new mould that was made specifically for this figure. It&#39
column3: s visually appealing, but the moulded detail is great as well! It consists of three different colours: the peach bun, the dark red hot dog, and the yellow-orange mustard. That sculpt pegs into the head using an anti-stud, but it extends upwards past the head, and downwards past the legs. The colour choice for the bun is perfect, in my opinion, since it doesn&#39
column4: t clash against the head. On that note, this head piece is incredibly useful! This chipper, toothy grin is exquisite, and so simple, yet super effective.

column1: This weiner lacks torso printing, but I will admit, it'
column2: s great seeing&nbsp
column3: a minifigure torso and arms caste in peach. I also love this dude&#39
column4: s pants, which are incredibly useful&nbsp
column5: in light blue without printing, since they resemble pants.

column2: t have an accessory, which makes complete sense, thanks to the new hot dog piece. This is the perfect LEGO Minifigure! It has a well-thought of concept that was extremely fresh and unique, and its executed so darn well, with nice colours and prints. This is an easy 5 out of 5 for me, and it is undoubtedly amongst my favourites in the series.
